title: Trade Turmoil Strains Emerging- Market Currency Rally
summary: Investors pull back on risk in the midst of renewed U.S.-China trade tensions and falling commodities. This year's rally in emerging-market currencies is facing a test as investors pull back on riskier bets in the midst of renewed trade tensions and falling commodity prices.

title: McGahn Rebuffed White House Request to Say Trump Didn't Obstruct Justice
summary: After release of the Mueller report, the president sought to have the former White House counsel say that he didn't believe the president's push to dismiss the special counsel constituted a crime. WASHINGTON-Within a day of the release of the Mueller report last month, President Trump sought to have former White House counsel Don McGahn declare he didn't consider the president's 2017 directive that he seek Robert Mueller's dismissal to be obstruction of justice, but Mr. McGahn rebuffed the request, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: How Virginia's Top Democrats Survived a Storm of Scandal
summary: The media lost interest in the Northam blackface brouhaha when it realized the GOP could benefit.. Drive around Northern Virginia, and you'll see no sign that only three months ago, the state was the epicenter of one of the most embarrassing and horrifying political scandals in recent memory. In the populous suburbs west of Washington, plenty of cars still sport bumper stickers proclaiming support for Gov. Ralph Northam, Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax and Attorney General Mark Herring-Democrats all.

title: The Yeoman Work Behind 5G Wizardry
summary: Tomorrow's wireless world may be a revolution as promised. But Qualcomm's Dino Flore tells how the tech is forged slowly in a world-wide effort.. San Diego

title: Uber's High-Profile IPO Upsets With Weak Debut
summary: Company's shares closed their first day of trading at $41.57, blemish for San Francisco-based company. Uber Technologies Inc. skidded into the public markets Friday, falling 7.6% below the ride-hailing giant's already conservative offering price in a bleak debut for the nation's most valuable startup.

title: GM and Boeing Show How Safety Miscues Happen
summary: Each design choice may be imperfect, but it takes a piling up of circumstances to create a fatal defect.. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg's comments at the company's annual meeting last month left many baffled. Why not acknowledge that Boeing had screwed up with its now-notorious MCAS software that contributed to two fatal crashes of its new 737 MAX jets? His performance left a different taste in the mouths of specialists: The lawyers are in charge now.

title: The Divine Artistic Hand in My Late Mother's Beauty
summary: As I sketched her face, I reconnected with her, and with a creative pursuit from my childhood.. As a child, I was encouraged to practice the arts. I took piano lessons and was given paper and paints with which to draw. My parents praised me for writing stories, poems, and plays and pushed me to recite and perform them for company. I did these things with pleasure until my teens. Although I went on to study literature and write essays and books as part of my vocation, I did so in the prescribed, often ugly style of academic discourse-without the whimsical and graceful manner in which I wrote as a child.

title: The China Trade Impasse
summary: The tariff damage rises as Beijing backtracks on its earlier concessions.. Stock markets stabilized Friday after President Trump called the latest round of U.S.-China trade talks "constructive." That seems to be the case to the extent that the two economic giants agreed to keep talking, not that they are closer to a deal. Prepare for some collateral economic damage as the two sides ratchet up their dueling tariffs.

title: Tax Reform's Blue-State Dividend
summary: Look whose budgets are benefitting from the Trump tax reform.. Democrats claim that Republican economic policies are sinking blue-state budgets. But it turns out a rising economic tide from tax reform and deregulation is lifting tax revenue in most states, including those governed by Democrats.

title: Help Wanted in the U.S.A.
summary: More guest workers would ease the growing labor shortage.. The Trump Administration said this week that it will grant an additional 30,000 seasonal H-2B visas this summer, and the workers can't come soon enough. The U.S. has more job openings than unemployed workers, according to the latest Labor Department's JOLT survey, and the workforce gaps are growing fast.

title: Zillow Sees a Future in House Flipping
summary: The company's once and current CEO says skeptics are wrong about the company's new business. Few entrepreneurs have turned as many online ventures into household names as Rich Barton. In his 20s, he started Expedia . com within Microsoft Corp., then spun off the travel-booking site in 1999. Spotting a similar opportunity to make real-estate listings and employer reviews more transparent, he co-founded Zillow Group and Glassdoor in the following decade, leading Zillow as its chief executive from 2005 to 2010 and afterward as its executive chairman.

summary: Gone are the days when new hires spent years learning the ropes before being handed important work. The Class of 2019 will be thrown right into the fray.. Dear college graduate:

summary: United Capital manages some $24 billion in client assets. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is near a deal to acquire wealth-management firm United Capital Financial Partners Inc., expanding its push into managing assets for individuals, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Higher operating costs offset modest growth in revenue per available room. title: Dollar Reverses Losses
summary: Hopes of a positive outcome to flareup between U.S., China push some investors out of the yen. The dollar reversed earlier losses against the Japanese yen on Friday, after President Trump said that trade talks with China will continue and hinted that tariffs could be ended.

title: Roberto Calasso's 'The Unnamable Present' Review: Sacrifices at Modernity's Altar
summary: Terrorism turns murder into meaning. Strikes on public spaces target the archetypal locales of secular society.. Roberto Calasso is our foremost interpreter of the mythology of modern life. This is a tremendous achievement, because modern life is not supposed to have a mythology. We are supposed to live in what Max Weber called a disenchanted world, with rational systems all around us, and above us, as John Lennon said, only sky. The history of the secular West, however, proves this frame of mind to be neither tenable nor rewarding. We remain Homo religiosus, and those who believe in nothing keep falling for anything.

title: The Successful Asylum Seeker Who Now Drives Uber
summary: Immigration and American vitality.. The public debut of Uber, the largest initial public offering since 2014, hasn't quite lived up to expectations today. title: Treasurys Pare Gains as Investors Focus on Trade

summary: Lawsuit says retailer risking problems with lenders in proxy fight. summary: Trump administration says it will sanction supporters of the Maduro regime. title: Fight to Revive South Africa Awaits Ramaphosa After Bruising Election
summary: Set for the weakest national result on record, South Africa's ruling ANC could turn on its own in ideological battle over economic overhauls. title: The Social Secret That Humans Share With Ants
summary: Building giant communities of strangers requires 'markers' that let members know who does and doesn't belong. A quick way to understand how humans are different from most other mammals that live in societies is to observe what happens when one of us enters a crowded coffee shop: basically, nothing. No random chimpanzee could stumble across a crowd of unfamiliar chimps without reacting in fear or setting off a killing frenzy. People, by contrast, are fundamentally more comfortable with strangers. We had to be, for our planet-dominating societies to expand into populations in the tens and hundreds of millions.

title: With Trade Deal in Jeopardy, Trump Pledges Aid to Farmers
summary: Administration signals it is ready for a prolonged standoff as new tariffs on China take hold. WASHINGTON-With a U.S.-China trade deal in danger of collapse, the Trump administration said it will begin work on a new program to provide aid to farmers-sending a signal to Beijing that Washington is preparing for a prolonged conflict.

title: U.S. Bolsters Its Gulf Defenses to Counter Iran
summary: Pentagon to deploy Patriot antimissile system, assault ship as officials say Tehran shows no signs of changing posture. The U.S. military plans to deploy a Patriot antimissile system to the Persian Gulf area and will beef up its naval presence in response to growing threats from Iran, the Pentagon said Friday.

title: LVMH Launches New Fashion House With Rihanna
summary: Fenty is a bet that recording artist can bring the same cachet as industry's celebrity designers. title: Lawmakers Plan Would Let Borrowers Cancel Student Loans in Bankruptcy
summary: Senate bill, backed by Dick Durbin and Elizabeth Warren, would affect $1.5 trillion in federal student loans. Federal lawmakers on Thursday introduced a bill that would give student loan borrowers the power to leave that debt behind when they file for bankruptcy protection.

title: Karen Russell's 'Orange World and Other Stories' Reviewed: Dreams in Full Color
summary: Russell-with help from her vampires, devils and shape-shifters-exposes the strange in the familiar landmarks of American culture and history.. Iimagine things about Karen Russell. I imagine that when she was growing up, teachers probably told her that she "lived too much in her own head." I think she was the kind of girl who had a box turtle as a pet and made skirts for it out of tinsel. I suspect she didn't go to her senior prom-or if she did, she went with the turtle.

title: The Modern Side of Ancient Venice: A Traveler's Guide
summary: For those who think they've 'done' Venice, think again. As the Venice Biennale-the world's biggest art fair-kicks off this weekend, we highlight the city's newer, must-see attractions. STARTING THIS WEEKEND, Italy's most magnetic tourist town plays host to the Venice Biennale, the vast international art show that runs through November. Unsuspecting vacationers expecting to binge primarily on Renaissance painters and gothic palaces are in for a surprise.

title: Facing Floods, Towns Call for New Controls on the Great Rivers
summary: 'Something needs to change,' says one governor as flooding along the Missouri and Mississippi rivers worsens and comes more frequently. Alton, Ill., a tourist town on the edge of the Mississippi River, has been fighting floods about every eight months for the last six years. This week's crest, which ranked No. 7 among the city's 10 worst floods, forced the closure of the city's riverboat casino, left its riverfront park underwater and closed portions of its downtown.

summary: Democrats push through package of more than $19 billion; talks continue in Senate over funding for Puerto Rico. title: Sports Gear Designed for Women's Bodies-Not Stereotypes
summary: From sneakers to space suits, most gear is still designed for men's bodies. How to avoid brands that just 'shrink it and pink it' and find bikes, kicks and backpacks that fit you right. WHEN IT COMES to sports gear and apparel, women don't always get what they want-and they rarely get what they need, which in the worst cases can lead to life-affecting injuries. In an essay published by the Guardian in March, cyclist Hannah Dines detailed her experience having to undergo surgery after years riding bike saddles that didn't properly pressure-map her groin led to chronic inflammation and long-term trauma. She had just trained through the pain. While men can comfortably straddle most bike seats, she wrote, "female cyclists sit right on the money."

summary: Balter Capital Management plans to close fund backed by family behind OxyContin maker. The Sacklers' potential financial liability from a raft of lawsuits stemming from the opioid crisis made their long-term commitment to the fund uncertain, he said.

title: Saving Capitalism and Free Markets by Fiat
summary: Capitalism doesn't need saving. The free market isn't meant to "work" for anyone in particular. This is John Hickenlooper's fatal conceit.. I give John Hickenlooper credit for the proper premise-capitalism is good-but for little else ("I'm Running to Save Capitalism," op-ed, May 6). If he really wants to save capitalism, he should discuss the need for enhanced individual responsibility, not more government programs. Lamenting the inability of 40% of the population to cover an unexpected $400 expense without discussion of why this is the case does a huge disservice to your readers.

title: More Government Isn't the Repair We Need
summary: Many people still agree on limiting government power and entitlements, encouraging free enterprise and reducing our worrisome level of debt.. Peggy Noonan calls for a new conservatism to reunite the Republican Party, but it appears to me that her new conservatism is driving the party apart and disenfranchising the silent majority of moderate voters ("Republicans in a Nation Needing Repair," Declarations, May 4). These voters simply want to focus on what Ms. Noonan refers to in her opening paragraph as "old conservatism." Many people still agree on limiting government power and entitlements, encouraging free enterprise and reducing our worrisome level of debt. Far fewer subscribe to new conservatism's social values, many of which should be regarded as personal matters of faith rather than part of a party platform.

title: Some Facts About Michael Cohen That Are Indisputable
summary: The Aug. 1 check was an installment payment on the advance hush money payment made by Mr. Cohen to implement that hush money scheme-for Mr. Trump's, not Mr. Cohen's, benefit.. Regarding George Sorial's "Michael Cohen Was a Bluffer, Not a Fixer" (op-ed, May 6): It is not unusual that someone known as a Trump apologist resorts to personal attacks while ignoring indisputable facts presented by Michael Cohen at his Feb. 27 public hearing before the House Oversight Committee.

title: Feeding a Family Isn't a Job for Mothers Alone
summary: In an era of processed foods, wholesome home cooking is more important than ever-and men need to share that burden.. This Sunday, millions of women will be served breakfast in bed, made by childish hands. Mother's Day is a rare occasion when children make food for their mothers rather than the other way around. The toast may be burned and there may be crumbs in the sheets for days afterward, but it is the thought that counts. The meals of Mother's Day are a tiny sliver of payback, a recognition that taking on the responsibility of feeding another human being is hard, important work that deserves to be celebrated.

title: A Town That Changed Literature
summary: A vibrant cast of characters populates Sherwood Anderson's unorthodox short story collection 'Winesburg, Ohio.'. In the decade following World War I, American literature enjoyed a flourishing of new authors and literary fare. While some of the more sweeping manifestations (Modernism, the Lost Generation) had obvious European roots, homegrown movements were making an indelible mark. Chicago was especially alive with literary activity, and it was here that Sherwood Anderson (1876-1941), a small town businessman from Elyria, Ohio, came in 1913 to test and, he hoped, round out his evolving authorial skills.

title: How a Pocket Knife Saved the 'John Wick 3' Director's Life
summary: Chad Stahelski, who served as a stuntman for 'The Matrix' and helmed 'John Wick 3' on waxing his jackets, relying on knives and the $100k chopper he's too afraid to ride. It carries the right amount of kit without bogging me down. I just used it in the Sahara while shooting desert shots for "John Wick 3"-loaded with water bottles, a camera, a lens, everything.

title: Manet's Late 'Spring'
summary: Even as his health declined, the painter's work remained energetic and innovative.. The J. title: Arvi Parbo Rose From an Estonian Dairy Farm to Top Posts in Australian Mining

title: Jerrie Cobb Passed Astronaut Tests but NASA Kept Her Out of Space

title: Meet the Sound Editor Bringing 'Toy Story 4' Characters to Life

title: Are the New Spider-Like Chandeliers Just Creepy?
summary: Some interior designers are rejecting traditional dining-room chandeliers for ones that sprawl across ceilings with swags of exposed wires. But are they too weird? We asked nine décor pros to thrash it out. Fans of this fixture say it sets their spidey senses tingling in a good way. Manhattan architect Michael K. Chen, who installed the FLOS Aim pendants in the New York apartment, likes the way their loose formality contrasts with the formal, prewar architecture: "We weren't going to select some musty crystal chandelier for this project." Chicago architect-designer Steve Kadlec finds the matte black finish unifies the installation's components: "You see it as a single, sculptural fixture even though it has all these parts." Another fan, New York designer Marina Hanisch, recently placed an Apparatus Lariat fixture, which suspends teardrop-shaped glass orbs from brass-mesh cables. "The different heights bring more interest to a room," she said. Pamela Babey of San Francisco design firm BAMO traces the origins of the chandelier's industrial style to Europe, where historic buildings force designers to handle wiring in interesting and unusual ways. Closer to home, she installed Edwin Lutyens's tasseled Cardinal Hat pendant lights, linked by swagged cables, in a large, contemporary kitchen and dining space with only one electrical box. "We wanted light in different parts of the room, and the cables traveled from the kitchen sink to the table," she explained. Mr. Chen faced a similar problem: an electrical source that wasn't directly above the dining table. "We needed a fixture that was a little free-form."

title: John Paul Stevens Worries About the Court
summary: A retired Supreme Court justice wants his former colleagues to adhere to precedent and the president to comply with subpoenas. At 99, John Paul Stevens can remember a time when a Supreme Court nomination prompted minimal controversy, confirmation hearings proceeded without made-for-television speechifying and senators unanimously approved an unblemished nominee.

title: Mysteries: A Curse on the Crown Prince of Satapur
summary: Perveen Mistry, an Oxford-educated lawyer in 1920s Bombay, finds herself called to a remote mountain kingdom.. Perveen Mistry, the Oxford-educated lawyer in 1920s India who starred last year in Sujata Massey's "The Widows of Malabar Hill," has many reasons to keep her guard up. A Zoroastrian in a land of mostly Hindus and Muslims, Perveen must be tactful in the face of others' beliefs. An admirer of Gandhi's activism, she needs to avoid alarming the British colonialists she depends on for employment. Estranged from her husband but not formally divorced, she has to be scrupulous in her social behavior lest she damage her own and her family's reputations.

title: Inside the More-Is-More World of Luxury Yachts
summary: Ferretti's CEO talks about how superyachts vary by market, and some of the most outlandish amenities customers ask for. And get.. The 2008 financial crisis ravaged luxury-goods companies making everything from $3,000 shoes to multimillion-dollar cars. Things were no different for Italian superyacht maker Ferretti Group, which builds boats that can cost tens of millions of dollars. Revenue and profit plunged while a heavy debt load taken on to fund a series of acquisitions pushed the company to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: IFM Investors to Buy Buckeye Partners for $6.5 Billion
summary: Buckeye's shares climbed 27% in premarket trading to $41.41 a share. Australian-based IFM Investors has agreed to acquire Buckeye Partners LP at a value of $6.5 billion.

summary: Pyongyang's short-range missiles resemble a Russian Iskander, which can carry nuclear warheads, experts say. SEOUL-The short-range missiles tested by North Korea can strike much of South Korea and may be able to carry a nuclear warhead, military experts said, providing Pyongyang with extra firepower as diplomatic frictions grow with Washington.

title: U.S. Increases Tariffs on China as Talks Resume
summary: President says U.S. would impose fresh levies on $325 billion in Chinese goods as negotiators move to salvage potential deal. title: Uber Owns Its Lane
summary: Ride-hailing giant takes valuation cut in IPO, but still holds a unique position against other big unicorn debuts. Google is the name of a company that also happens to be listed as a verb in the Merriam-Webster dictionary. So are FedEx and Xerox. Uber -already used as shorthand across much of the world for the act of calling up a ride from a smartphone-is likely next.

title: Brexit Preparation Helped Speed Up U.K. Economy
summary: Growth accelerated as businesses prepared for a possible 'no deal' exit from the EU in the first quarter. LONDON-The U.K. economy picked up speed at the beginning of 2019, as businesses readied for the country's now delayed exit from the European Union, though prospects for the year as a whole remain muted as uncertainty over Brexit drags on.

title: Europe Now Belongs to the Premier League
summary: For the first time in the history of the Champions League and the Europa League, all four spots in the finals will be occupied by clubs from a single country. The whole point of Europe's two biggest soccer tournaments, the Champions League and the Europa League, is to pit the best of the best from every country against each other. Each competition takes 10 months to unfold and crosses dozens of borders. The idea is to finish with four clubs, the cream of the continent, duking it out for European supremacy in a pair of glittering finals.

title: Retailers Are Warned to Step Slowly Into One-Day Shipping
summary: Supply-chain experts say delivering as expected rather than sheer speed can matter most to online consumers. Retailers anxiously watching Amazon.com Inc.'s one-day shipping push need to get a better handle on their inventory and true demand for super-speedy delivery before setting on a costly scramble to match the e-commerce giant, analysts and industry executives say.

title: U.S. Consumers Poised to Take the Hit From Higher Tariffs on Imports From China
summary: Increased duty of 25% touches everything from fish sticks to baseball mitts. WASHINGTON-The round of tariffs that went into effect at midnight will likely hit Americans in the pocketbook, making $40 billion of consumer goods on retailers' shelves more expensive.

title: The Surprising Tax Bill for Children of Gold-Star Families
summary: A change to the 'Kiddie Tax' is raising taxes for children of service members who died on duty-and on many other young people. Rebecca Headings's husband, U.S. Navy Senior Chief Petty Officer Gary Headings, died of a heart attack at age 39 in 2017.

title: A Vulnerable U.S. Really Does Need a Space Force
summary: China and Russia are developing new weapons that can attack crucial American satellites, and the U.S. has been slow to respond to the danger. In May 2014, a small team at the Joint Space Operations Center at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California noticed something they had never seen before. A Russian rocket had lofted a communications satellite into space, along with what appeared to be the usual collection of space junk-ranging in size from massive spent rocket stages down to chips of paint. But a few weeks later, one piece of that "junk" came to life.

title: Shipowners Seek to Slow Services to Meet Emissions Limits
summary: 'Slow-steaming' plan divides maritime operators, with critics calling it a smokescreen that will delay cargo deliveries and investment in cleaner vessels. Looming new environmental regulations are triggering sharp divisions in the shipping industry between vessel operators investing billions of dollars to reduce emissions and others who want to stave off the financial impact by simply slowing down ships.

title: The New Cities for New Grads: Salt Lake City, Pittsburgh and Baltimore

They are also among the most expensive, and affordable rents are often far from the action.

summary: Just when the business environment was improving, private companies look set for another hit. After a brutal patch late last year, private companies in China finally thought things were looking up. The Trump administration is threatening to cut the party short.

summary: Resume Subscription. The sudden deterioration of trade talks between the U.S. and China this week has raised the prospect of a once-unimaginable rupture between the world's two largest economies.

title: 'Ghosts of Gold Mountain' and 'The Chinese & the Iron Road' Review: Building the Transcontinental Railroad
summary: The men who laid tracks across the Sierra Nevada were mostly immigrants from Guandong, China.. On May 10, 1869, at Promontory Summit, Utah Territory, Leland Stanford drove home a ceremonial gold spike to mark the meeting of the eastern and western lines of the Transcontinental Railroad. Nearly seven years earlier, President Abraham Lincoln had signed the Pacific Railroad Act, which lavished unprecedented financial inducements in the shape of land grants, loans and bonds on the Union Pacific Railroad and the Central Pacific Railroad, of which Stanford was co-founder. They soon began to lay rail lines toward one another across the vast, rugged West.

title: Five Best: Alexandra Popoff on Russia and the Soviet Union
summary: The author, most recently, of 'Vasily Grossman and the Soviet Century' writes about works that illuminate people, places and time periods.. By Anne Applebaum (2017)

title: Fiction: Russian Nightmares, American Dreams
summary: Novels that collapse the void between East and West, past and present, Earth and moon.. The Kamchatka Peninsula, the strip of land that curves like an earring below Siberia, was a closed territory during Soviet rule, its proximity to the United States making it so geopolitically valuable that citizens needed military clearance to enter it. In Julia Phillips's debut, "Disappearing Earth" (Knopf, 256 pages, $26.95), longtime residents of Kamchatka think longingly of the era of enforced isolation. Revmira, a member of the region's indigenous Even people, recalls an "idyllic village, a principled people, a living Even culture, a socialist nation of great achievement." To Valentina, a Russian school official, trouble started with the appearance of tourists and migrants. Unreliable nostalgia, a fear of new arrivals-a chronicler of our contemporary moment could find much the same attitudes without crossing the street, much less crossing the globe. Thus the fascinating paradox of Ms. Phillips's novel, which is set in one of the most remote and mysterious places on the planet, but whose concerns are instantly, and disturbingly, recognizable.

title: Care.com Boosts Vetting After Scrutiny
summary: Online child-care network plans in-depth background checks and lowers annual guidance. Online child-care marketplace Care.com Inc. said it plans to overhaul its business model to include in-depth background checks and other screening procedures for caregivers after its vetting practices came under scrutiny.

title: 'Dinosaurs Rediscovered' Review: No Longer Dragging Their Tails
summary: Dinosaurs long had been depicted as gray or brown tail-draggers. But many living reptiles are brightly colored, so why not dinosaurs?. The Mesozoic era, which began more than 250 million years ago, is probably as close as we will get to an alien living world-a world profoundly different from the biosphere in which humans evolved and now live. Dominating that world were, of course, the dinosaurs. These marvelous animals filled thousands of niches in nature and ranged in size from creatures smaller than a chicken to 70-ton monsters more than 120 feet from nose to tail tip, the largest beings to have ever walked the earth.

title: 'Origins' Review: The Earth and Us
summary: Geology is destiny: Humans' flexible intelligence emerged as a response to a rapidly changing landscape.. Curving across America's Deep South is a "Black Belt" that runs from western Tennessee down to Montgomery, Ala., then back northeast through the Carolinas. During the 2016 presidential election, this swath was an anomaly of Clinton Democrats surrounded by a sea of Trump Republicans. It coincides with a demographic belt dominated by African-American voters, which, in turn, lies above a geological belt of soft rock: a band of nutrient-laden shale created about 75 million years ago when sea levels stood much higher than today. When weathered into soil, this shale is perfect for growing cotton, a cash crop planted at a time when chattel slavery was an accepted way of life, and when the water-powered textile mills of New England were hungry for raw material.

title: 'Blood, Oil and the Axis' Review: The Front That Was Left Behind
summary: What if, at a crucial moment 78 years ago, Hitler had turned south instead of east? What if he had taken Suez, the Levant and Mesopotamia? The idea is not so far fetched.. Spring of 1941. Less than a year after the Nazis took Paris, Western Europe belongs to Hitler. To the east, the Soviet Union is a much weaker force and still Germany's ally. In the U.S., isolationism, with pro-German sympathy in certain quarters, keeps the free world's greatest power out of the war. All that stands in Hitler's way is the British part of the English-speaking world.

title: 'Becoming Dr. Seuss' Review: Who Killed Dick and Jane?
summary: By the mid-1960s, 'See Spot Run!' had given up the game to 'Hop on Pop!' Subversive insouciance is now part and parcel of beginner books.. In the fall of 2017, there was a furor involving Dr. Seuss, the first lady and a school librarian that many people found surprising and disconcerting. In celebration of National Read a Book Day, Melania Trump had sent a parcel containing 10 Seuss titles to a school in Massachusetts. A librarian there rejected the gift.

title: Postmates Watching Uber's Market Debut as It Prepares for Summer IPO
summary: Uber's stock-market performance could have impact on competitors' valuations. Uber Technologies Inc.'s stock performance following its expected Wall Street debut Friday could have significance for a range of companies in ride-hailing, food delivery and other emerging transportation services.

title: Trump Backs Push to Limit Surprise Medical Bills
summary: Big charges from out-of-network doctors are a top concern of patients. President Trump threw his support behind efforts to tackle surprise medical bills, wading into a turf war between hospitals, doctors, and insurers over how patients are charged for treatment outside their insurance network.

title: Wynn Resorts Revenue Falls as High Rollers Slow Spending
summary: Casino operator swings to profit after year-ago results included charge related to a legal settlement. High rollers, the big spenders who have fueled much of the gambling action in years past, shied away from Wynn Resorts Ltd. in the latest period, causing the casino operator to miss Wall Street revenue targets.
